Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 11:08AM BMac wrote: Love your post Melinda.  If you're snippy and bitter then kudos to you cuz I'm snippy and bitter too! I blame Oprah for the whole getting cancer is a blessing/gift.  She's actually said this on her show when trotting out some celebrity who is now "cured".  People like Oprah (who I don't really have anything against per se) perpetuate this image of the positive, courageous cancer survivor who beat the disease and is now stronger and better than ever. No one wants to hear about the dark moments, about the fear or about those women who are stage IV and can't put it behind them because they're living with it everyday.  I've had cancer twice, ovarian in 2002 and breast in 2007 and, believe me, these days I'm looking over my shoulder.
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 11:16AM BMac wrote: Coolbreeze, thank you, thank you, thank you!  I read your friend's blog and love every word of it.  You see I lost my mother to ovarian cancer on November 5, 2001 and ten months later I was diagnosed with stage III ovarian cancer.  I'm still here 8 years later and have been told that I've beaten the odds.  I feel very fortunate but also find it chilling. I have posted on this site about how lonely ovarian cancer can be.  You don't have the support or the attention.  There are few women to support you because so few make it.  A Toronto television show a few years back had their entire audience made up of women who were going to walk in the annual "Weekend To End Breast Cancer" in support of the Princcess Margaret Hospital.  I politely emailed them asking if they could include other women's cancers in future especially as September is Ovarian Cancer Awareness month and this show aired in September. I received a polite response saying they would consider it and, of course, nothing happened.  I am pleased to report however that the walk has this year changed to the "Weekend to End Women's Cancers".  Now that's progress. As annoying as Pinktober is, it's better than being ignored.  I remember walking in Costco a few years ago and stopping dead in my tracks.  An ovarian cancer PSA was running on a TV and I had to stop in shock to actually hear anything about ovarian cancer. So thank you again for sharing.
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 07:34AM BMac wrote: Just a caution, knowing you're BRCA1 doesn't ensure it's being caught early.  I was being screened for BC and still found it at stage III.  I wish I had had a prophylactic bilat mast.
Posts.Title: family and cancer mpieterse LumiPojo

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 07:23AM BMac wrote: When you're fighting for your life there's no such thing as over treating!  When my doctor gave me my diagnosis my first question was what stage am I (this was well before surgery).  He hesitated and then said it was a late stage III.  I felt at that time that he was even thinking stage IV.  I thought my life was over. I've had cancer twice and both times I wanted them to do everything possible to ensure that I got better and was around to see my children grow up.  Two out of three have now done that and I feel much more hopeful than I did two years ago.
Posts.Title: Stage 3 and 4 over treated? RANT LittleC lorieg

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2008 02:19AM BMac wrote: Dear Tweeker I am BRCA1.  My sister (then 32) was diagnosed with Breast cancer in 1992 (still living).  My mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at age 61 in 1994.  At that time alarm bells went off and my sisters and I started going to the Familial Ovarian Cancer Clinic in Toronto. My mother died in 2001 after several recurrencies and a year later I was diagnosed with ovarian cancer.  My sisters and I had the genetic testing at that time and I was referred to a high risk breast cancer clinic.  At that time the doctor mentioned the possibility of prophylactic mastectomy but said I should find out my prognosis first; in other words, why put yourself through all that if you aren't gong to be around much longer. He left and I was referred to another doctor and, when I asked her about it, she didn't recommend it.  Fast forward to October 2007 and I was diagnosed with breast cancer, late stage three, lymph nodes involved and because the lymph nodes behind the breastbone were involved and couldn't be operated on I started with chemo, followed by surgery, soon to be followed by radiation and Herceptin is also ongoing.  I can't have reconstruction until after the radiation and have to wait to make sure it doesn't come back. So the right mast was prophylactic.  I wish someone had hit me over the head  and told me to have the double mastectomy several years ago.  I could have avoided all of this.  I think my doctor should have told me to have it.  Obviously hindsight is 20/20 but I was at HIGH risk so why didn't anyone lay it on the line? My advice would be to have it done if you feel you are high risk.  I thought I would be devastated losing my breasts but, surprisingly, I'm not that bothered (I'm 55; maybe that helps, but still was very happy with my breasts!).  I'm glad I had both off.  I think just having one breast would be more difficult to deal with.  This way I have a matching pair. Best of luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: prophylactic mastectomy-your input wanted tweekerbeeker lilith

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2008 06:02AM BMac wrote: Dear Colleen, I am BRCA1.  I had the testing done, along with my sisters after I got ovarian cancer and 10 months after my mother died from it.  My sister had breast cancer in 1992.  I had a complete hysterectomy at the time (2002). I was diagnosed last fall with breast cance and at that time it was a no brainer to take both breasts.  I knew that would be the case even before I met the oncologist for the first time.  My thinking has always been that I will do anything I have to do to ensure that my children don't lose their mother.  My youngest was almost 10 last time and is 15 this time around.  The thought of my children has made my decision making easier.  However, I haven't had to go through this alone.  I'm sorry that  your husband isn't there for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 08:21AM BMac wrote: I was sad to hear this too.  She was a lovely lady and a great actress.  My hearts goes out to her two sons.  My biggest fear with my two cancers was always leaving my children without a mother.  It's interesting debating the sudden death vs. knowing someone is dying.  My sister-in-law said on the weekend that it would be better knowing someone was going to die (my father-in-law passed away on Feb 8th).  That really got my back up as I lost both parents to cancer.  I told her there's nothing easy about watching someone you love die, feeling sick to your stomach the whole time.  Plus my father was only 56 when he died 25 years ago.  My father-in-law was 88 and the one thing that helps me is knowing he had a long, fairly healthy, life. I guess knowing gives you the opportunity to say goodbye and make the most of time you have with them.  Having said that, sudden or not, a young child losing their mother is never easy.

Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 07:42AM BMac wrote: Barbe, have you thought of phoning your doctor's office and asking them to fit you in for an earlier CT?  When I was waiting for my scans when my lump was first found I phoned my doctor's secretary and told her I was very uncomfortable waiting so long.  Lo and behold a cancellation came up on a day when I was at Mt. Sinai for a bone scan.  The secretary was to meet me to give me the contrast solution for the scan.  She had just received a cancellationn for one of their patients and actually walked me to the booking dept and made the change right there and then.  I didn't even have to be agressive or even assertive.  Sometimes just asking the question will get results.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 07:50AM BMac wrote: I had terribly runny eyes.  I have allergies so I'm always blowing my nose and everytime I blew my nose my eyes would squirt.  Very annoying.  I happened to go to the opthamologist for a routine visit while on Taxotere and mentioned the problem.  No one associated it with the drug and they told me it was probably an eye duct problem that could be operated on.  Needless to say the problem went away after finishing Taxotere.  I don't remember how long after but not very long...weeks rather than months, I think.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 10:51AM BMac wrote: Do it when you're ready; there's no rush.  I had mine done on April 30/08 and got my prostheses on Sept 22/08.  I knew I had to wait til I healed from surgery, then I was having rads and it isn't recommended to wear prostheses during rads because of the irritation.  I got used to not having anything and, like you, was in no rush.  Once I got them I was very happy with them.  I guess the timing was just right. After surgery I wore a camisole that I got at the hospital with pockets for foam inserts.  They did the trick til I went for the "real" things.  That way I looked like I had breasts but it was incredibly comfortable.  This may be an option until you're ready to commit.  Prostheses aren't cheap!

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 12:55PM BMac wrote: I'm not stage IV but have had stage III ovarian and stage III bc.  When the doc was giving me the news, before any surgery he hesitated about the stage and I really thought he was thinking possibly stage IV.  Believe me I know how lucky I am and realize "There but by the grace of God go I". Mazy, I'm aboslutely appalled by your treatment regarding the support group.  Those people should be ashamed of themselves.  What's the point of a support group if it doesn't offer support!  Unbelievable. The whole Oprah thing makes me seethe.  She likes happy endings and positivity.  It's not always possible to be positive no matter what stage you are but no one wants to hear about that.  Wouldn't it be wonderful if Ellen stepped up to the plate.  A few years ago Oprah had a breast cancer special and the Komen sister was on and it was very moving.  Then Christina Applegate came on with her new breasts touting that she was cured!  Wow, it was hard to swallow. People want to sweep Stage IV under the carpet.  No one wants to think it can happen to them.  What's awareness if we ignore those people who need us the most?

I do daily self massage and go for a professional massage once a month only.  I am happy to report that I am now able to wear my wedding ring again.  My index finger is permanently swollen but not noticably so to others.

Posts.Title: a doctor in ontario prestressed BMac

Posts.Content: BMac wrote: It was one year ago today that I got the dreaded phone call.  My husband and I had just got home from Costo and there was a message on the machine.  Essentially, the routine MRI I'd had 10 days before showed something and could I come in the next day, as the doctor who read the MRI would be at Princess Margaret Hospital that day and wanted to be the one to do an ultrasound. I knew in that moment that I had cancer.  When I arrived the next day I was given a form re Care After Biopsy.  I said "I'm getting a biopsy?".  The receptionist said "That's just in case they decide to do one."  Nice recovery.  Then when I was in the waiting room waiting to be called two ladies came to talk to me about being in a clinical trial!  It seemed like everyone else knew what was going on before I did.  Anyway, I didn't qualify for the trial as I'd had chemo before (for ovarian cancer). So I had a mammo, ultrasound and biopsy of the breast and node.  I asked the doctor if she thought it was cancer and she said "Yes".  It just confirmed what my gut was already telling me.  So like most people in my position I was hoping for Stage I.  That was dashed when I found out I had at least one node involved.  Okay, I thought, so Stage II.  That was crushed when a cat scan revealed that the lymph nodes behind the breastbone were involved and they can't be operated on.  The surgeon, when pressed, hesitated and said a late stage III but I felt like he was hesitating because he thought maybe even Stage IV.  I thought at that moment that it was the end of the road for me.  Luckily for me the chemo shrunk the tumour as well as the lymphs and the surgeon was thrilled with the results. So here I am one year later with more of my innocence dashed and having had to face my own mortatlity yet again.  You see, I had Stage III ovarian cancer six years ago.  What is it with the number III.  I still feel like I'm in a bad dream and can't believe that I had to go through all of this again.  Will I ever feel normal again? Barbara Dx 10/23/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 1/13 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 11:38AM BMac wrote: Dear Mary I haven't seen anyone recommend Kytril (common name Granesetron).  I had it during my Ovarian treatments and during my  first three breast cancer treatments.  It is given via IV during treatment and orally after.  It's heavy duty and causes constipation.  I always popped a dulcolax as soon as the iv came out and everyday until I went. I'm in Canada so I don't know if it's given in the States or is prescribed under another name but it sure worked for me. Barbara
Posts.Title: anti-nausea drugs mary6204 leaf

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 02:15PM BMac wrote: Oh Kira, I feel for you having it in your dominant hand.  That makes things so much more difficult.  I realize how lucky I am (if having early stage lymphedema can be considered lucky!). Writing is something that I would think would have the potential to exacerbate the lymphedema.  Can you use the computer instead of writing or is it filling in forms?  My last job required filling in forms which I was able to set up on the computer, pre-cancer so nothing to do with lymph, just quicker and more efficient to do things on the computer.

Posts.Content: BMac wrote: My husband and I celebrated our 30th wedding anniversary by going to Stratford  to see two plays and stayed at a B&B overnight.  After dinner the first night we had a bit of time to kill before the play to so we went to Shoppers Drug Mart to buy toiletries we had forgotten to bring. We decided to use the blood pressure machine since we were there and it was there...DH went first then me.  I put my arm in and pressed the button and just as the cuff was starting to inflate I realized I HAD MY AFFECTED ARM IN THE CUFF!  DOH! I shrieked and pulled my arm out and DH said "What happened?".  I explained and then proceeded to reset the machine, sit in the chair backwards and get my BP.  I can't believe I almost did that.  It just goes to show how easy it is to do.  Thank goodness! Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2008 01:57PM BMac wrote: Dear Lynette, so sorry you had such a rough time.  I found the FEC caused me a lot of nausea.  I didn't get the dex for the nausea until the third treatment and it did help a bit more with the nausea.  Is your problem that you forgot to take your meds i.e. fell asleep?  Is there someone living with you who can take charge of this and make up a schedule and make sure you take everything on time? My nurse recommended that I take the nausea meds before I felt nauseated, so preventatively rather than after the fact.  It seemed to work better.  Water is the best thing to drink to flush your system.
Posts.Title: My first FEC.... Lynette bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 01:05PM - edited Sep 27, 2009 01:05PM by BMac Yes, I have lymphedema; just mild.  It started with my hand getting puffy last October.  I've been to a lymph clinic three times since then and the last time (a few weeks ago) the measurements have come down.  The only thing I can see now is some puffiness in my index finger. I do manual lymphatic drainage as well as exercises they showed me on a daily basis and about once a month I go for a professional MLD.  I wear a sleeve and glove when I life weighs and when flying.
Posts.Title: Close Call BMac kira

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 10:38AM BMac wrote: Hi, Michele, I'm the opposite of you.  I had a bliat mast in April 08 and wanted immediate reconstruction but my  surgeon said I have to wait two years because of the chance of recurrence. I now have very slight lymphedema and my lymphedema massage therapist is cautioning me against recon.  The one thing I have most been looking forward to is recon and it upsets me that I may not be able to have it. I have prostheses and I have to say that they are very realistic.  I look like my "old" self so am very happy with them.  I suppose it wouldn't be the end of the world if I have to stay the way I am, I'm just limited with necklines. Having said all that, it is your decision.  Don't let anyone push you into something you're not ready to do.  It's major surgery and if you're not ready to do it now, wait.  You can get it done in the future and give yourself time to go through treatments and heal.
Posts.Title: need more support for my decision MicheleS melissa-5-19

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 01:54PM BMac wrote: Love this thread.  Even though neither of my cancers were hormone positive, no doctor will prescribe estrogen.  I asked my BC onc last week about estring (which I heard about right here on good old BCO) and she thinks that would be okay and recommended I go see a gyn so I had my family doctor refer me so I'm now waiting to get the referral. This is one side effect (in my case of menopause) that doctors seem to ignore.  They don't seem to have any solutions and we're just expected to put up with it.  This is one area where we really have to become our own advocates.  Thanks to all the wonderful ladies here that are helping us to be able to have sex again without pain.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 02:45PM BMac wrote: Not to bust anyone's bubble but MRI's don't necessarily mean your cancer will be caught early.  I was being screened for BC at a high risk clinic (here in Ontario) with annual MRI's and annual mammograms.  My BC was found on the MRI and I was stage III.  By the way, I don't have dense breast; in fact, I don't have breast at all anymore!
Posts.Title: Dense breasts.....demand mri Naomi evieo

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 09:43PM BMac wrote: I, too had a son away at school.  I found out on 10/23/07 that I'd had an abnormal MRI.  Meeting with doctors and having a bone scan and CT  and then waiting for results took until the end of Nov.  We hadn't told anyone because we didn't want to take a chance that the kids would hear it from anyone else. (Hubby told a few very close friends).   We waited until a week and a half before my son was coming home for Christmas to tell the other two and then I swore them to secrecy until Bill came home.  He had exams and I didn't want him worrying, also, as others have said, I wanted to tell him in person.  I had ovarian cancer in 2002 and if it wasn't for the fact that I was going to lose my hair (and therefore had to tell them) I would have been very tempted to not tell them at all.  I hated to put them through that again.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 12:26PM BMac wrote: Dear Lashon, I did chemo first followed by bilat mast and left node removal (I am BRCA1, hence they took both) and then rads (3 more to go).  In my case it was because the lymph nodes behind the breastbone were involved and they can't operate on them.  They told me ahead of time they can tell right away if the chemo is working and they could (and it did work). When I had my surgery my surgeon was absolutely thrilled with my path report and said that I had done very well.  I'm sorry you're going through this at such a young age.  Good luck.

Posts.Title: Chemo Brain Ok, but chemo vagina? Help!!!! Shanagirl BlondiShanagirl

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 05:10AM BMac wrote: Hi Leah, I'm so sorry about your Mom.  What a rollercoaster this dreaded disease is.  I started chemo on Nov 29/07 and did three FEC followed by three Taxotere; that's when I started my Herceptin as well, which I will be finished in January. I won't lie to you.  I found Taxotere to be brutal.  I also took steroids with it:  the day before, day of and the day after.  What I found was that I had lots of energy due to the steroids for several days after chemo.  By about four days after I crashed.  The nurse said it was due to coming off the steroids so the second time they weaned me off the steroids by reducing the dosage for several more days.  What this did was just delay the crash so I think the Taxotere had a lot to do with how I felt. For about four days (give or take a day) I would by almost comatosed in that all I could do was lay on the couch.  Some days I was lucky to have the energy for a shower.  One time I almost passed out.  By about one and a half weeks after the chemo I would feel better again. I also got bad mouth sores.  Each time they got worse and lasted longer.  The doctor prescribed a mouth wash which you swish around and then swallow (to get the sores in the very back of the mouth).  By the third treatment I was drinking the mouthwash many times a day! Taxotere also weakens your nails.  I had several fall off.  This isn't as bad as it sounds.  By the time the nail falls off you have a new "baby" nail underneath.  Several ladies I see when I go for Herceptin were just recently on Taxotere and two of them ended up in the hospital.  This was due to getting a fever so just watch her temp and go to the emergency if she gets a fever. I don't want to scare you but just make you aware so that you know what to expect and know that she will get through it.  After all, I did. Best of luck to you and your Mom.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) anyone? lemon_acosta MrsJMS

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2008 03:09PM BMac wrote: I cried a lot before the bilat mast.  Unfortunately, I have to wait for reconstruction.  I always felt that I would have felt better if I had been able to start recon right away, but who knows?  I went for a consultation for a tram flap but that isn't possible because I've had radiation on my entrie abdomen for ovarian cancer.  So now I'm waiting for another consultation for another type of recon. Surprisingly, not having breasts hasn't been all that bad.  I guess in the grand scheme of things I'd rather have my life than breasts.  That being said I still intend to get recon and wish I could do it right now but it will happen soon enough.

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2008 02:29PM BMac wrote: Why are we women so nice?  Some of us (and I include myself here) wouldn't say sh*t if we had a mouthful of it.  I AM getting better but I find myself nodding in agreement with you ladies.  Yes, I would have been alarmed but no I probably wouldn't have said anything (for fear of offending?). On an aside, I was at a Food Court a few years ago and went to the washroom first.  I was washing my hands when a worker from Manchu Wok came out of the stall and left the washroom WITHOUT WASHING HER HANDS!!!  I had been planning to eat there before this incident but quickly changed my mind.  Now maybe she had just been adjusting something, not actually using the facilities or maybe she washed her hands when she got back but that wasn't a chance I was willing to take.
